title: Behavioral Analysis of Information Salience in Large Language Models
author: Jan Trienes (Marburg University), Jörg Schlötterer (University of Mannheim), Junyi Jessy Li (The University of Texas at Austin), Christin Seifert (Marburg University)
relevance_why: The methods developed for analyzing information salience in text summarization could be adapted to improve audio-captioning tasks, particularly in discerning which audio aspects to emphasize.
background: The paper investigates how Large Language Models (LLMs) prioritize information in summarization tasks by analyzing the salience of content based on specific questions.
contribution: This paper introduces a framework utilizing length-constrained summarization and question answerability to derive models' grasp of information salience, achieving a nuanced understanding of content selection.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior research primarily focused on frequency-based content selection or human-derived supervision signals, lacking systematic exploration of models' inherent salience.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work innovates by combining behavioral probes with question-based analysis to objectively assess content salience across multiple models.

key_innovation: Combines length-constrained summarization with Questions Under Discussion to derive a measurable framework for information salience in LLMs.
real_world_impact: This research may enhance tools for automatic summarization and content generation, leading to better information retrieval systems across various domains. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: The research findings show weak alignment with human perceptions of salience, limiting their application for subjective content assessment.

new_terms.Questions Under Discussion (QUDs): **Questions Under Discussion** are inquiries that capture the essential topics of discourse, serving as a mechanism to analyze information selection and relevance.
new_terms.Content Salience Maps (CSMs): **Content Salience Maps** are matrices used to systematically represent and track how different topics are prioritized in summaries of varying lengths.

open_sourcing: The authors have released code, model outputs, and human annotations at https://github.com/jantrienes/llm-salience.
